author: By Lauren Hirsch and Michael Corkery
title: How Tyson Foods Got 60,500 Workers to Get the Coronavirus Vaccine Quickly
description: The meatpacking giant, which was criticized for failing to do enough to protect its workers from Covid-19 last year, has become a leader on corporate mandates.
content: SPRINGDALE, Ark. — When Tyson, one of the world’s largest meatpacking companies, announced in early August that all of its 120,000 workers would need to be vaccinated against the coronavirus or lose their jobs, Diana Eike was angry. Ms. Eike, an administrative coordinator at the company, had resisted the vaccine, and not for religious or political reasons like many others here in her home state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: What the vaccine deadline means for you.
content: The Biden administration said today that large companies have until Jan. 4 to ensure that their work forces are vaccinated against Covid-19. The new health measures apply to companies with more than 100 employees and cover about 84 million private sector workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy K. Smith and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: We Feel Now a Largeness Coming On
description: Tracy K. Smith reminds us how “being called all manner of things / from the dictionary of shame,” we do learn to become something mighty.
content: I think of Juvie, so named because he walked into prison with so few laps around the sun. Think of how so many of us have been named convict and number. I know his state number, but will keep it to myself. Now Juvie has died just months after freedom and Tracy K. Smith reminds me that, “being called all manner of things / from the dictionary of shame,” we do learn to become something mighty, with the memories of those fallen. Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: N.F.L. Week 9 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
description: The Rams’ upgraded defense will try to stall the Titans, and Kansas City will face the Aaron Rodgers-less Packers.
content: The N.F.L.’s trade deadline was as notable for the players who didn’t get moved as for the players who did. The Los Angeles Rams added the Pro Bowl linebacker Von Miller to an already tremendous defense, but the long-rumored Miami Dolphins trade for Deshaun Watson did not come to pass, and Odell Beckham Jr. is still (at least nominally) a member of the Cleveland Browns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: He Can’t Cure His Dad. But a Scientist’s Research May Help Everyone Else.
description: The muscle wasting disease that has debilitated Sharif Tabebordbar’s father motivated a life in science that led to an important medical discovery.
content: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — When Sharif Tabebordbar was born in 1986, his father, Jafar, was 32 and already had symptoms of a muscle wasting disease. The mysterious illness would come to define Sharif’s life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: A deal to end the use of coal.
content: A coalition of 18 countries, plus dozens of banks and other institutions, will pledge to phase out coal-fired power plants domestically and to end funding for international coal projects. The burning of coal is the single greatest contributor to climate change, and ending support for it has been a key focus at the U.N. climate change conference COP26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Neena Pathak, Diana Nguyen, Luke Vander Ploeg, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: A Rough Election Night for the Democrats
description: Why did the party fare so poorly in Tuesday’s closely watched contests?
content: At first, most of the attention on a major night of elections across the United States on Tuesday was on an unexpectedly close contest in the Virginia governor’s race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins, Aina J. Khan and Megan Specia
title: Britain Becomes First to Authorize an Antiviral Pill for Covid-19
description: The authorization of Merck’s easy-to-use Covid treatment, molnupiravir, is a step toward taming the pandemic.
content: Britain became the first country on Thursday to authorize the use of an antiviral pill for Covid-19, an easy-to-use treatment that could help tame the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Six Things We Recommend This Week
description: Sun-kissed wines from the South of France, musings from Tom Ford — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: New York Democrats Assess Their Losses: It Was a ‘Shellacking’
description: Quotation of the Day: Thursday, November 4, 2021.
content: “There’s no way to sugarcoat this: This was a shellacking on a thumping.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Pamela McCorduck, Historian of Artificial Intelligence, Dies at 80
description: She interviewed many of the scientists who were at the heart of the field through the end of the 1970s, and she compiled a groundbreaking history of its early years.
content: Pamela McCorduck, whose encounters with eminent computer scientists in the 1960s and ’70s led her to write a groundbreaking history of artificial intelligence over the field’s first 20 years, died on Oct. 18 at her home in Walnut Creek, Calif. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: What Can Older Generations Learn From Gen Z?
description: What is unique about your generation? What attitudes about fashion, work-life balance or political activism might benefit older generations?
content: What is unique about Gen Z? What are some of the qualities — good and bad — that define your generation? Have you found older generations accepting of those qualities?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Hawaii is easing restrictions and preparing to welcome back tourists.
description: The state is eager for its vacation industry to rebound after a devastating 2020 season.
content: Signaling that Hawaii is eager to jump-start its battered tourism and hospitality industries, Gov. David Y. Ige said that his state would ease Covid restrictions this month and welcome international travelers again, under new federal guidelines that go into effect on Nov. 8.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘All Is Forgiven’ Review: A Distinctive First Feature
description: A father with a drug problem tries to reconnect with his daughter.
content: Mia Hansen-Love’s latest film, “Bergman Island,” is a simultaneously enigmatic and provocative treatment of the knotty intertwining of life and art. Her first feature, “All Is Forgiven,” from 2007, is getting its U.S. debut this week, and it confirms that the writer-director’s beguiling (and to some, confounding) cinematic voice was all but fully mature from the start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Why Biden Donors Are Frustrated: Hurt Feelings and Voting Rights Alarm
description: Some of the top Democratic contributors have become increasingly dissatisfied with a lack of communication from the White House — and impatient with inaction on voting rights.
content: As Joseph R. Biden Jr. hopped from Manhattan high-rises to Silicon Valley mansions to gather campaign checks in 2019, he developed a certain way of thanking the well-heeled donors who invested in his presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What Students Are Saying About Climate Anxiety, Football Controversies and Making Choices
description: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
content: Welcome to our roundup of student comments on our recent writing prompts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: California Tries to Close the Gap in Math, but Sets Off a Backlash
description: Proposed guidelines in the state would de-emphasize calculus, reject the idea that some children are naturally gifted and build a connection to social justice. Critics say math shouldn’t be political.
content: If everything had gone according to plan, California would have approved new guidelines this month for math education in public schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: What’s the Matter With Scarsdale?
description: Democrats’ struggles with working-class voters seem to be getting worse.
content: They are among the most affluent places in America: Arlington, Fairfax and Loudoun Counties, in Northern Virginia; Upper Montclair, N.J.; Scarsdale, N.Y.; Wilmette, Ill.; Palo Alto and Malibu, Calif; and Mercer Island, Wash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Passes First Budget in More Than 3 Years in Lifeline for Government
description: The vote raised hopes that the country might be headed for a period of more political stability after the chaos of four elections in quick succession.
content: JERUSALEM — Israel’s Parliament narrowly approved a state budget on Thursday, the country’s first in more than three years, removing an imminent threat to the survival of the government that could bring some political stability after a chaotic stretch of four elections within two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: OK, but What Should We Actually Do About Facebook? I Asked the Experts.
description: Assessing the many ideas for fixing the social network.
content: One of the most unsettling revelations in the cache of internal documents leaked by the former Facebook employee Frances Haugen has been just how little we know about Facebook, and consequently how unprepared our political culture is to do anything about it, whatever it is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carolyn Finney
title: Who Gets Left Out of the ‘Great Outdoors’ Story?
description: You’ve heard of Davy Crockett. Now meet Lancelot Jones, Sylvia Stark and other Black outdoors pioneers who can redefine our notion of the natural world.
content: In 1987 I embarked on a six-month backpacking trip around the world. The adventure ignited a love so fierce for the feel of the earth beneath my feet that I spent the better part of five years traveling through Africa and Asia, returning home in between trips to earn enough money so that I could hit the trail once more. (The Black author and activist bell hooks once told me of my travels, “That’s the ‘Eat Pray Love’ I want to read.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: With Climate Pledges, Some Wall Street Titans Warn of Rising Prices
description: Leaders of some of the world’s biggest financial firms say that the rush to transition to clean energy could have unintended consequences for the global economy.
content: GLASGOW — Big business finally seems to be taking the climate crisis seriously. After years spent lurking on the sidelines, the chief executives of the world’s largest banks, companies and investment firms this week took a spot at the center of the debate at COP26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: A White House aide who traveled abroad with Biden tests positive for the coronavirus.
description: President Biden was not in close contact with the aide, who remains quarantined in Scotland and has not shown symptoms of Covid-19.
content: WASHINGTON — A White House aide who traveled with President Biden to Scotland tested positive for the coronavirus this week and remains in quarantine abroad, according to an administration official who spoke on the condition of anonymity to describe a medical issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: The Forgotten Nursing-Home Tragedy
description: Covid deaths are again on the rise in elder-care facilities. Does anyone care?
content: For many of the most vulnerable people in our society, the pandemic has not let up. More than 186,000 residents and staff members of nursing homes and long-term-care facilities have already died of Covid-19. In March, the Covid Tracking Project estimated that nearly 1 in 10 people who lived in nursing homes in the United States had died of the virus. And a report released by the Kaiser Family Foundation in early October showed that during July and August of 2021, the number of Covid deaths inside nursing homes had started to rise again, reaching its highest level since February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: A More Satisfying Meatless Meatball
description: Once you find the perfect base of beans, vegetables and grains, the possibilities are endless.
content: I make my veggie koftas, or meatballs, from a base of soft, half-mashed black beans seasoned with ginger, garlic and chiles, bake them in the oven until they’re nice and crunchy on the outside, then dunk them in spicy tomato sauce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Finch’ Review: Three for the Road
description: Tom Hanks, a dog and two robots take a post-apocalyptic road trip in this unexciting drama from Apple TV+.
content: The science is sparse, but the sentiment is several inches thick in “Finch,” a post-apocalyptic road movie in which Tom Hanks spends almost two hours scavenging for a plot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Center of Italy’s Anti-Vaccine Protests Is Now a Covid Hot Spot
description: After leading the resistance to the government’s new health pass, the northeastern port city of Trieste is home to a worrying spike in cases.
content: TRIESTE, Italy — When Italy introduced Europe’s toughest and most expansive health pass last month, the northeastern port city of Trieste became the epicenter of protests as vaccine skeptics marched alongside dock workers who shouted that the measure infringed on their right to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: U.S. Sets Jan. 4 Vaccination Deadline for Big Private Employers
description: The new guidance will cover 84 million workers, who will be required to be fully vaccinated or be tested weekly.
content: The Biden administration on Thursday set Jan. 4 as the deadline for large companies to mandate coronavirus vaccinations or start weekly testing of their workers, the government’s biggest effort yet to enlist private businesses in combating the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Azzopardi
title: ‘A Man Named Scott’ Review: Bending Genres, Coping With Struggles
description: This film about Kid Cudi is that rare musician-focused documentary, one as sensitive, fully formed and noble in its intentions as the artist himself.
content: In “A Man Named Scott,” a documentary about Kid Cudi, the genre-defying rapper’s longtime friend, Shia LaBeouf, and one of his superfans, Timothée Chalamet, are among the men who say Cudi helped them open up emotionally. They acknowledge Cudi for reshaping hip-hop on his own terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Bringing Books to Children That Speak Their Language
description: Nonprofit groups focused on literacy are encouraging reading and engaging students through culturally relevant stories.
content: “I’ve never had a book of my own before.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: 5 Takeaways From the First Days of the Climate Summit
description: The world leaders have left Glasgow. Now negotiators must hunker down to turn pledges into reality.
content: GLASGOW — Presidents and prime ministers have left town. Now the hard work starts, with diplomats hunkering down in a cavernous tent complex at the U.N. climate talks here for the next week and a half, trying to hammer out deals to cut planet-warming emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Ew, David, Your Book Is a Best Seller!
description: What went on behind the scenes on “Schitt’s Creek”? Now readers can find out.
content: SCHITT’S PEAK In the darkest, loneliest, most discombobulating days of the pandemic, the six-season series “Schitt’s Creek” provided unexpected solace. Its viral stardom made a certain kind of sense: The show follows the travails of a formerly wealthy family that finds itself marooned in a roadside motel in a nowheresville town, with little hope of returning to a familiar life and the most rudimentary tools for building a new one. Who couldn’t relate to the Roses’ slow-dawning realization that the world had irrevocably changed?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Winter Movies 2021: Here’s What’s Coming Soon to Streaming and Theaters
description: Get ready for originals like “House of Gucci” and “C’mon C’mon” or franchise updates like “The Matrix Resurrections” and “Ghostbusters: Afterlife.”
content: Tired of critics raving about film festival titles that you haven’t yet had a chance to see? This holiday season will bring many of the year’s most acclaimed films to theaters and streaming, from Jane Campion’s “The Power of the Dog,” which will be available both ways, to the Thai director Apichatpong Weerasethakul’s “Memoria,” which is forgoing home viewing altogether. There will also be fresh takes on enduring classics of the stage: Steven Spielberg does “West Side Story,” while Joel Coen adapts Shakespeare in “The Tragedy of Macbeth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins and Nate Schweber
title: Bones in the Backyard: How Police Cracked a Grisly Cold Case
description: George Seitz’s disappearance in 1976 drew little notice — until investigators found his skeleton in a backyard more than 40 years later.
content: On Dec. 10, 1976, George Clarence Seitz left his home in Jamaica, Queens, to get a haircut and never came back. His disappearance drew little attention at the time and was all but forgotten in the 45 years that followed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Jonathan Weisman
title: House Democrats Hunt for Votes to Pass Biden’s Domestic Agenda
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi wanted a vote on Thursday night on a $1.85 trillion social policy and climate bill, but moderates pushed back and action was postponed until Friday.
content: WASHINGTON — House Democrats are scrambling to line up the votes needed to push through a $1.85 trillion social safety net, climate and tax bill, as moderate Democrats, spooked by Tuesday’s electoral drubbing, have raised concerns about the cost and details of the rapidly evolving plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Nelson Freire, Piano Virtuoso of Warmth and Finesse, Dies at 77
description: Hailing from Brazil as one of the great pianists of the last half of the 20th century, he recalled masters of the first half in his virtuosity. But he shunned the limelight.
content: Nelson Freire, a reclusive pianist whose fabled technique and sensitive, subtle musicianship made him a legend among pianophiles, died on Monday at his home in Rio de Janeiro. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Dan Hinkel
title: 4 Takeaways From the Kyle Rittenhouse Homicide Trial
description: On the fourth day of the trial, jurors were shown graphic videos from the chaotic night in 2020 when shootings broke out after demonstrations in Kenosha, Wis.
content: The fourth day of the Kyle Rittenhouse trial in Kenosha, Wis., was marked by graphic video of the shootings on Aug. 25, 2020, and by emotional testimony by a witness who was only feet away from Mr. Rittenhouse as he shot and killed Joseph Rosenbaum, one of three men who were shot that day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: South Korea will hospitalize all Covid patients taking the college entrance exam.
description: The decision comes as the country experiences rising caseloads again. The nine-hour test is seen as critical in determining students’ futures, and many have prepared for it since kindergarten.
content: South Korea said on Thursday that it would hospitalize even asymptomatic high school seniors with Covid if they are taking the country’s high-stakes college entrance exam later this month, as the drive to vaccinate younger people lags and teenagers account for nearly a quarter of all Covid patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Edie Falco Shines as an Everywoman in ‘Morning Sun’
description: A new play by Simon Stephens has hearty performances but a nearly undetectable pulse.
content: Making the best of the little you’ve got may or may not be the theme of “Morning Sun,” the pianissimo new play by Simon Stephens that opened Off Broadway on Wednesday. But it’s certainly the problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Behind Tyson’s Risky Bet on a Vaccine Mandate
description: The meatpacking giant took the lead on corporate vaccination rules despite uncertainty on how employees would react.
content: When Tyson Foods announced in August that it would require coronavirus vaccines for its entire work force, it was arguably the boldest corporate vaccine mandate at the time. Several companies already required vaccines for white-collar employees, but labor shortages made most reluctant to do the same for frontline workers, who were less likely to be vaccinated and most likely to be exposed to the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: ‘Europe is back at the epicenter of the pandemic,’ a W.H.O. official says.
description: The World Health Organization said Europe was responsible for nearly three-fifths of the world’s recent coronavirus cases, and that deaths in the region were surging.
content: Europe is again experiencing near-record levels of coronavirus cases, and could experience half a million Covid-related deaths in the next three months, the World Health Organization said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Karen Zraick
title: N.Y. City Council Sees Historic Changes, and Republicans Gain Ground
description: Concerns over public safety and pandemic restrictions helped some Republicans win seats on the New York City Council, which will also be one of the city’s most diverse councils ever.
content: Election Day was expected to be something of a historic moment for the New York City Council. The city’s legislative body was poised to welcome its first South Asian members, its first Korean American members, its first Muslim woman and its first out L.G.B.T.Q. Black women. For the first time, it would have more women than men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George A. Hirsch
title: How the New York City Marathon Grew Up
description: It started as four laps in a sketchy park, and now the race is a global phenomenon, back after a year lost to the pandemic.
content: Back in 1970, when the first New York City Marathon was run, it was something very different than we know today: four laps around Central Park, which was hardly the pastoral jewel that New Yorkers now know and love. It was marred by rampant vandalism, drugs were sold openly at Bethesda Fountain and graffiti defaced most of its buildings. The park’s dangers were so well known that any mention of a nighttime stroll there was a surefire laugh-line on the Johnny Carson show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Ciattarelli Dominated in New Jersey. When It Came to Lawn Signs, That Is.
description: Did that matter? Maybe a little.
content: I told people on Monday that I thought Jack Ciattarelli would do better in the race for governor of New Jersey than the polls were indicating. My unscientific rationale was that Mr. Ciattarelli, the Republican challenger, had many more lawn signs than Gov. Phil Murphy where I live, northeastern Bergen County. I would estimate that Mr. Ciattarelli had at least 10 times as many signs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Do Generations Matter? Well, Maybe.
description: Emma Goldberg recently wrote about the tension between Gen Z employees and millennial bosses. The article sparked spirited — and sometimes, heated — debate online. Here, she explores the need to categorize ourselves into generations.
content: When I started middle school, the quiz-industrial complex was booming, which meant I spent much of sixth grade mulling over a set of complex questions: If I were a Hostess snack, which one would I be? Pasta shape? Dog breed? Character in “Full House”? Which house would I have landed in at Hogwarts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Senate Confirms Robert Santos as First Latino to Lead U.S. Census Bureau
description: The confirmation on Thursday brings a permanent head to the agency after a turbulent period under the Trump administration.
content: The Senate on Thursday confirmed Robert Santos as head of the Census Bureau, making him the first person of color to serve as permanent director of the agency that counts the United States population, balances the number of electors to the Electoral College and tracks changes to demographics and wealth in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Deep in a new surge, Germany sets a daily virus case record.
description: The country registered 33,949 new coronavirus cases over a 24-hour period on Wednesday, surpassing a high set in December of last year.
content: Germany recorded 33,949 new coronavirus cases over a 24-hour period on Wednesday, surpassing a record set in mid-December 2020, when the country was in the throes of its second Covid wave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: The U.S. trade deficit rose as a surge of imports bogged down the supply chain.
description: The trade deficit in September climbed to $80.9 billion, a record. Imports rose slightly, while exports fell.
content: The U.S. trade deficit hit a record $80.9 billion in September, reflecting a surge in imported goods that continued to outpace American exports, data released by the Commerce Department on Thursday showed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Frequently Asked Questions About the Biden Administration’s Vaccine Mandate
description: We’re answering your questions about the new OSHA rules for employers with 100 or more workers. This F.A.Q. was last updated at 7 p.m.
content: Corporate America has entered the next phase of its effort to counter the spread of the coronavirus. Companies of 100 or more employees have until Jan. 4 to ensure all their workers are either fully vaccinated or submit to weekly testing and mandatory masking. The measure was announced by President Biden in September, and details were released on Nov. 4 by the Labor Department’s Occupational Safety and Health Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Hive’ Review: In the Aftermath of War, a Survivor Finds Herself
description: In a tough, taut drama, the director Blerta Basholli explores the lives of women whose husbands went missing in the Kosovo War.
content: The spare, tightly wound drama “Hive” opens with the movie equivalent of a hand grabbing your throat. An unsmiling woman with a hard, monumental profile stands alone next to a truck. People mill around nearby, murmuring indistinctly. Abruptly, the woman ducks under some police tape and into the truck, where she hastily begins unzipping one white body bag after another and just as quickly scanning their contents, her nose wrinkling at the exposed bundles of tattered clothing, remnants of missing persons. She’s soon ejected by a worker, but her search continues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Lepore
title: Elon Musk Is Building a Sci-Fi World, and the Rest of Us Are Trapped in It
description: From Mars to the metaverse, tech moguls are forging a new kind of capitalism: an extreme, extraterrestrial version.
content: The last week of October, Bill Gates (net worth: $138 billion) celebrated his 66th birthday in a cove off the coast of Turkey, ferrying guests from his rented yacht to a beach resort by private helicopter. Guests included Jeff Bezos (net worth: $197 billion), who after the party flew back to his own yacht, not to be confused with the “superyacht” he is building at a cost of more than $500 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘Dexter’ and the Shows That Wouldn’t Die
description: The revival of the serial-killer drama is TV’s latest refusal to let a supposedly finished franchise rest in peace.
content: The first thing to die in “Dexter: New Blood” is irony. The murder weapon is the subtitle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb and Kevin Draper
title: What to Know About the Robert Sarver Racism and Sexism Allegations
description: Sarver, who owns the N.B.A.’s Phoenix Suns and the W.N.B.A.’s Phoenix Mercury, has been accused of using racial slurs and making sexual and other inappropriate comments.
content: The N.B.A. and W.N.B.A. have opened an investigation into Robert Sarver, the owner of the Phoenix Suns and Phoenix Mercury basketball teams, after current and former employees accused him of racist, sexist and other inappropriate behavior in an ESPN report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: Blue Origin Loses Legal Fight Over SpaceX’s NASA Moon Contract
description: A federal judge rejected the argument by Jeff Bezos’ rocket company that NASA unfairly awarded a lunar lander contract to Elon Musk’s firm.
content: A federal judge on Thursday rejected Jeff Bezos’ latest legal attempt to overturn NASA’s multibillion-dollar moon lander contract with Elon Musk’s SpaceX. The decision ended a monthslong battle between the space companies of two of the world’s richest men that posed a significant obstacle to NASA’s plans for returning humans to the moon for the first time since 1972.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Is Meta’s Facial Recognition Retreat Another Head Fake?
description: If ever an issue cried out for some lawmaking guidance, this is it.
content: Facebook, oops, Meta — boy, this is going to take some getting used to — announced this week that it would end its decade-old facial recognition system and delete the face data of over a billion users, prompting the cybersecurity reporter Kashmir Hill of The New York Times to tweet, “My jaw dropped to the floor.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope and Tony Cenicola
title: The 2021 Well Holiday Gift Guide
description: Share the gift of healthy living. Here’s a list of some of our favorite things, from the staff and contributors of Well.
content: For the 2021 Well Holiday Gift Guide, we’re sharing 21 of our favorite things that can make life just a little better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: The Whole World
description: What message do you think this GIF is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘Greta Thunberg Has Given Up on Politicians’
description: In this short video, the 18-year-old Swedish activist argues that we can’t look to politicians to solve the climate crisis; instead, she says, it’s “up to you and me.” What gives you hope in the fight against climate change?
content: “Greta Thunberg Has Given Up on Politicians” is an eight-minute film profiling the 18-year-old Swedish activist Greta Thunberg who calls our climate and ecological emergency “the biggest crisis humanity has ever faced.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: The Democratic Turnout Myth Unravels
description: It was long thought that surges in voting would help Democrats. So how does the party explain Glenn Youngkin’s victory?
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: How to Get Through a Pandemic Breakup
description: Even with life slowly creeping back to normal, a split from a partner during such stressful times can feel challenging.
content: When Carla Carreon and her boyfriend broke up in May 2020, a few months into the pandemic, “it was kind of like the worst storm,” she said. Ms. Carreon, 40, a marketing manager in San Francisco, had been with her boyfriend for three years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘North by Current’ Review: The Mornings After a Family Nightmare
description: In this documentary, the filmmaker Angelo Madsen Minax reckons with the loss of his niece, his vibrant sister’s rocky recoveries and being transgender in a traditional, Mormon environment.
content: “How did you become who you became?” asks Angelo Madsen Minax in the opening voice-over to “North by Current.” It’s one of many searching questions in Minax’s restless personal essay film about his family, himself and the ways in which we understand each other. Interlacing his visits to his folks in a Michigan lumber town with his reflections, the filmmaker reckons with the unfathomable loss of his niece, his vibrant sister’s rocky recoveries and being transgender in a traditional, Mormon environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘The Beta Test’ Review: Paranoia in Hollywood
description: Jim Cummings stars as a phony talent agent who agrees to an anonymous sexual encounter in this unruly satire.
content: In “Thunder Road,” Jim Cummings’s 2018 feature based on his short film of the same name, he used long takes to usher the audience through tragicomic vignettes in real time. Not so in “The Beta Test.” Here, Cummings — who wrote and directed the movie alongside PJ McCabe (they also both star in it) — experiments with a collage effect, marrying splintered images with a bombastic central performance to unspool an unruly, and sometimes muddy, satire of Hollywood gluttony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Teenagers in The Times: October 2021
description: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
content: Here is the October edition of Teenagers in The Times, a roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. We publish a new edition on the first Thursday of each month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Nick Corasaniti and Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Sues Texas Over Voting Restrictions
description: The department argued that a major voting law passed by Republicans would disenfranchise several groups of vulnerable Texans, including voters who do not speak English and those with disabilities.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Thursday sued Texas over the state’s new voting law, arguing that the Republican-led measure would disenfranchise Texans who do not speak English, people with disabilities, older voters and those who live outside the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: ‘Tick, Tick … Boom!’: A Musical Based on a Musical About Writing a Musical. We Explain.
description: Lin-Manuel Miranda’s directorial debut is an adaptation of a show by Jonathan Larson, creator of “Rent.” This guide unpacks the many layers.
content: Lin-Manuel Miranda’s new film adaptation of “Tick, Tick … Boom!” is the musical version of the “Rent” creator Jonathan Larson’s musical about writing a musical.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: In Spending Bill, Democrats Rely on Budget Gimmicks They Once Derided
description: Budget experts say true cost of legislation could be $4 trillion as lawmakers rely on sleights of hand to bring down the price tag.
content: WASHINGTON — At an impromptu news conference this week, Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, lamented the “shell games” and “budget gimmicks” he said his party was using to artificially reduce the $1.85 trillion price tag of the spending bill moving through Congress, saying the real cost was probably double that amount.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Lisa Prevost
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s homes are a five-bedroom in Lloyd Neck, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Greenwich, Conn.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Eternals’ Review: When Super Franchises Walk the Earth!
description: A pleasing cast and the director Chloé Zhao, who won a best picture Oscar for “Nomadland,” give Marvel’s latest a steady heartbeat.
content: Throughout “Eternals,” the latest — though certainly not the last! — from Marvel Studios, you can see the director Chloé Zhao fighting to cut this industrial-strength spectacle down to human size. Her efforts are mostly evident in the sincerity of the performances, and in the heartfelt moments that punctuate the movie, creating pinpricks of warming light. But it’s a titanic struggle. And as Zhao keeps lubricating the machinery with feeling and tears, her efforts seem to mirror the battle that her likable superheroes are waging against a force seeking to thoroughly control their destinies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Ivy Nicholson, Model and Warhol Factory Star, Dies at 88
description: She blazed through 1950s Europe as a top fashion model and then became a part of the 1960s Warhol crowd in New York before falling on hard times.
content: Ivy Nicholson was a working-class girl from New York City who lit up the 1950s as one of Europe’s top fashion models, married a French count, posed topless for Salvador Dali and became one of the first “superstars” in Andy Warhol’s Factory. It was a flashbulb life built on bravado and sheer magnetism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘A Cop Movie’ Review: When a Uniform Is a Costume
description: This strange and ambitious Mexican film plays like a combination of “Cops,” “F for Fake” and “When Harry Met Sally.”
content: Ambitious, heady and distinctive, if easier to admire in theory than engage with moment to moment, “A Cop Movie” has a conceptual strangeness that’s difficult to overstate. It’s as if someone combined “Cops,” “F for Fake” and “When Harry Met Sally.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Your Easy, No-Sweat Guide to Picking Wines for Thanksgiving
description: The grapes don’t really matter. Neither does where it was made. So long as it refreshes and rejuvenates, it’s the perfect bottle.
content: Thanksgiving 2020 was an anomaly, I hope, in which potentially ominous consequences disrupted what typically is a joyous gathering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Recaps Democrats’ Stinging Election Results
description: Stephen Colbert said Democrats are used to being disappointed: “That’s why they’re changing their logo from the donkey to Eeyore.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Dodge
title: The Ketamine Cure
description: The once-taboo drug has been repurposed to treat depression and is even available for delivery. But how safe is it?
content: Chris Gathman, 40, has lived with chronic depression, a condition that runs in his family, for most of his life. He’s used a combination of antidepressants and cognitive behavioral therapy to treat his symptoms, with limited success. In 2018, he sunk into an even deeper depression that began impacting his ability to socialize and complete daily tasks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Lisa Friedman
title: Over 40 Countries Pledge at U.N. Climate Summit to End Use of Coal Power
description: The United States did not agree to stop coal development at home but promised to halt overseas funding of oil, gas and coal.
content: GLASGOW — More than 40 countries pledged to phase out coal, the dirtiest fossil fuel, in a deal announced Thursday at the United Nations climate summit that prompted Alok Sharma, the head of the conference, to proclaim “the end of coal is in sight.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Meryl Streep for President
description: Meryl Streep explains how she prepared to play a fictional (and not especially competent) U.S. president in Adam McKay’s apocalyptic satire “Don’t Look Up.”
content: Who would you turn to if you learned a comet was on a collision course with Earth and decisive action was required to prevent the extinction of all life on this planet? If your first thought was Meryl Streep, you have made both an excellent and terrible choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison Moorer
title: This Part Is the Worst Part
description: The mother of a non-speaking autistic son yearns to know the answer to one simple question: ‘What is wrong?’
content: Singer-songwriter Allison Moorer has an 11-year-old son, John Henry, who was diagnosed with profound autism when he was 23 months old. His inability to express himself with words, and her inability to know how to help him in times of distress, remain the hardest issues for her to deal with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: It’s Time to Change the Clocks Again. Why Do We Do This to Ourselves?
description: Most Americans don’t like this disruptive ritual — but they’re split about which side of the clock-switching system they prefer.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Democrats Need to Confront Their Privilege
description: To win the culture war, bring the nation together, don't split it into parts.
content: One of the Democratic Party’s core problems is that it still regards itself mainly as the party of the underdog. But as the information-age economy has matured, the Democratic Party has also become the party of the elite, especially on the cultural front.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Camille Saviola, ‘Deep Space Nine’ and Stage Actor, Dies at 71
description: She was known for her comic work in cabarets, for her performance in the musical “Nine” on Broadway and for her role in a “Star Trek” spinoff.
content: Camille Saviola, an actress and singer who made an impression in the musical “Nine” on Broadway, in assorted cabaret spoofs and on television in “Star Trek: Deep Space Nine” and other series, died on Oct. 28 in a hospital in North Bergen, N.J. She was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Resources for Teaching About Climate Change With The New York Times
description: As world leaders and activists gather to discuss efforts to address the climate crisis, we offer dozens of resources to help students understand why our planet is warming and what we can do to stop it.
content: How much do your students know about climate change — what causes it, what its consequences are and what we can do to stop it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Which Cities Are Growing Most at the Expense of Others?
description: In recent years, metropolitan areas in the Sun Belt had the greatest gains in population from metro-to-metro moves.
content: Making a move from one city to another? You’re not alone. Populations in metropolitan areas are constantly shifting: Residents may be drawn in while jobs are plentiful, or forced out by rising rents. Maybe they’re starting a family or reaching retirement age and looking for a more suitable city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Futterman and Ashley Wong
title: The New York City Marathon Route: A Five-Borough Tour
description: The 26.2-mile race is a tour of New York City on foot, complete with roaring crowds scattered across diverse neighborhoods.
content: The New York City Marathon route spans all five boroughs, carrying runners across five bridges and several hilly stretches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: The U.S. Is Reopening. Here’s What Travelers Need to Know About Testing, Boosters and More.
description: Millions of travelers are expected to hit the skies and the road this holiday season. They will likely to have questions about the new regulations, which start Nov. 8.
content: On Nov. 8, the United States will lift an 18-month ban on international tourists, as long as they show proof of vaccination and a negative coronavirus test. The land borders with Canada and Mexico will also reopen for international visitors who are fully vaccinated and American citizens residing in those countries, as well as U.S. tourists returning home. Currently, passenger traffic in the United States is close to reaching 2019 levels, with millions of domestic travelers passing through Transportation Security Administration checkpoints each day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: NASA’s Latest Breakthrough: ‘Best Space Tacos Yet’
description: For the first time, astronauts on the International Space Station cultivated chiles, adding some zing to their tacos.
content: One small step for man, one giant leap for carne asada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: America Loves Choices. Not in Phones.
description: Why Apple and Samsung are the Coke and Pepsi of smartphones in the U.S.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Engage in Gasconade or Fanfaronade
description: In which I celebrate David Steinberg’s 100th crossword for The New York Times by getting hopelessly confused. But I learned two fabulous words, which made everything better.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — You would think that after all the time I have spent solving crosswords I would be prepared for and recognize just about anything, thematically speaking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: The Bank of England edges closer to raising interest rates, but holds steady.
description: Britain’s central bank said it would wait for more data on the labor market even as inflation is expected to climb to about 5 percent.
content: The Bank of England held interest rates at record low levels on Thursday, defying market expectations for a rate increase to tackle rising inflation. But the central bank said inflation would likely peak at about 5 percent in April, “materially higher” than its previous expectations, and signaled that rate rises were likely to be necessary in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Judge Questions Trump’s Grounds for Keeping Jan. 6 Documents Secret
description: In a hearing on Thursday, a federal judge voiced skepticism about the former president’s claim that hundreds of pages of documents related to the riot should be shielded by executive privilege.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Thursday expressed skepticism about Donald J. Trump’s attempt to block from release a wide range of documents related to the Capitol riot, signaling that she might be open to allowing a congressional committee scrutinizing the violence to pore over hundreds of files that the former president wants to keep secret.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Morrisroe
title: Annie Leibovitz, the Un-Fashion Photographer
description: “Fashion wasn’t anything I wanted to be involved with,” she says. Yet the visually arresting images in “Wonderland,” her new book and collection, may be her strongest work.
content: Annie Leibovitz would like to make one thing clear upfront: She is not a fashion photographer. Given that her new book, “Wonderland” (Phaidon) is an anthology of fashion images shot mainly for Vogue, that’s curious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Baffert, Barred From Churchill Downs, Is Embraced by the Breeders’ Cup
description: The Hall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert has longstanding relationships with many members of the Breeders’ Cup board.
content: The trainer Bob Baffert was barred from Churchill Downs and the Kentucky Derby after Medina Spirit failed a drug test in May shortly after winning the 147th running of America’s greatest horse race. The New York Racing Association has renewed its efforts to bar him from its circuit.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 13 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Our recommended books this week touch on everything from science and nature (in Mary Roach’s “Fuzz,” that means the collision of humans and other animals; in Thor Hanson’s “Hurricane Lizards and Plastic Squid,” it means the impact of climate change on nonhuman species) to politics (a biography of Angela Merkel, a look back at the tumultuous 1960s) to literature (the life of Elizabeth Barrett Browning, two takes on the meaning and importance of Black storytelling). Also, fine china. In fiction, we recommend new novels by Karl Ove Knausgaard and Claire Vaye Watkins, along with Gary Shteyngart’s pandemic-inspired narrative of friends and rivals locked down for the duration on a secluded country estate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: Effort to Reframe Climate Change as a Health Crisis Gains Steam
description: Research has increasingly shown that warming is taking a deadly toll on human health. At the global climate summit in Glasgow, the issue has gained new prominence.
content: For the first time at a major United Nations climate conference, human health is emerging as a leading issue, a reframing that brings climate change’s far-reaching and long-lasting effects to the forefront.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: What Red Flags? Elizabeth Holmes Trial Exposes Investors’ Carelessness
description: Start-up investors have often suspended skepticism while chasing a hot deal. The trial of Ms. Holmes, the founder of Theranos, has put that behavior under the spotlight.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — In 2014, Dan Mosley, a lawyer and power broker among wealthy families, asked the entrepreneur Elizabeth Holmes for audited financial statements of Theranos, her blood testing start-up. Theranos never produced any, but Mr. Mosley invested $6 million in the company anyway — and wrote Ms. Holmes a gushing thank-you email for the opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: In Florida, a Firestorm Over Silenced University Professors Grows
description: After the University of Florida blocked testimony in a voting rights lawsuit against the state, critics made accusations of political meddling. The governor denied the claims.
content: A decision by the University of Florida to bar three professors from testifying in a lawsuit against the administration of Gov. Ron DeSantis has ballooned into a political and public relations firestorm, one that could grow as other professors consider whether to step forward with stories of university pressure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: On the Agenda: ‘Get Stuff Done’
description: Eric Adams took a victory lap and said he would focus on public safety and the crisis at Rikers Island.
content: It’s Thursday. We’ll look at what Mayor-elect Eric Adams said about his plans for his administration — and what his sense of style says about him. We’ll also look at where Republicans made unexpected inroads in local races.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Norimitsu Onishi
title: Bitterness Over Brexit Lies Behind Fraying France-U.K. Relations
description: A recent dispute over fishing rights illuminates a broader and more fundamental disagreement over Britain’s decision to leave the European Union.
content: LONDON — On its face, the nasty squabble that broke out last week between Britain and France was over the fishing rights of a few dozen French trawlers plying British waters off the island of Jersey. As with many rivalrous neighbors, however, the root causes of the feud run far deeper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: facile
description: This word has appeared in 41 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Benedict Cumberbatch and the Monsters Among Us
description: The actor is earning some of the best reviews of his career for his turn as a vicious bully in “The Power of the Dog.” Here’s what it took to become that seething cowboy.
content: At the beginning of the shoot for “The Power of the Dog,” the ominous new psychodrama from Jane Campion, the director brought the actors and crew together on a remote and magnificent site on New Zealand’s South Island, which was standing in for the story’s Montana setting. After a Maori blessing, Campion began to introduce everyone. “This is Phil Burbank,” she said as Benedict Cumberbatch stepped forward. “Benedict is really nice and you’ll meet him at the end of the shoot.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Beans’ Review: Growing Up Fast in the ’90s
description: A middle school student comes of age during a standoff between the police and Mohawk residents during the 1990 Oka crisis in Canada.
content: The drama “Beans” sets its coming-of-age story during the 1990 Oka crisis, when Mohawk residents of Oka, Quebec, began protesting the expansion of a golf course into Native burial ground. The characters in the story are fictional, but “Beans” takes place during a real period of turbulence in Eastern Canada, as Mohawk people were harassed by their neighbors and the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Tracey Tully
title: Stephen Sweeney, N.J. Senate President, Loses to Republican Truck Driver
description: Mr. Sweeney, the second most powerful lawmaker in New Jersey and a Democrat, lost his bid for re-election to Edward Durr, a driver for a furniture chain.
content: For nearly a decade, Stephen M. Sweeney, the second most powerful lawmaker in New Jersey, seemed truly unassailable. He boasted deep ties to the most feared political power broker in the state and unyielding support from the influential building trade unions. Four years ago, the state’s teachers’ union spent more than $5 million to unseat him. He won by 18 points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Uber lost $2.4 billion, thanks largely to its Didi investment.
description: The quarter was otherwise upbeat, as business continued to rebound.
content: China’s crackdown on its big tech companies continues to have reverberations around the world. On Thursday, Uber said it lost $2.4 billion in its most recent quarter, largely because of its investment in the Chinese ride-hailing company Didi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: It’s Good to Be Golden State, Even Without Klay Thompson
description: Golden State is among the N.B.A.’s best teams, even without one of its best players in the injured Thompson. And it’s not just because of Stephen Curry.
content: There he was on the court before a game in San Francisco, dressed in the uniform the rest of his team would wear to play that night against the Charlotte Hornets — striped socks and all. Golden State guard Klay Thompson traveled around the arc for several minutes practicing 3-pointers.
source.name: The New York Times

description: This week’s properties are in Hell’s Kitchen and Sheepshead Bay, and on the Upper West Side.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: Do Gun Rights Depend on Abortion Rights? That’s Now Up to the Supreme Court.
description: The outcome of a Texas law targeting abortion will provide the answer.
content: It might have looked like a coincidence that questions of abortion and guns both reached the Supreme Court in the same week. But it wasn’t, really. Powerful social movements have devoted years to steering these two issues toward a moment of truth in a court reshaped in large measure by those same movements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Charlie Savage
title: Authorities Arrest Analyst Who Contributed to Steele Dossier
description: Igor Danchenko, a Russia analyst who worked with Christopher Steele, the author of a dossier of rumors and unproven assertions about Donald J. Trump, was indicted as part of the Durham investigation.
content: WASHINGTON — An analyst who was a key contributor to Democratic-funded opposition research into possible links between Donald J. Trump and Russia was arrested on Thursday and charged with lying to the F.B.I. about his sources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Greta Thunberg Says Climate Talks Are Becoming a ‘Greenwash Campaign’
description: Ms. Thunberg and other activists also spoke about the critical role that young women have played in pressuring world leaders to take action on climate change.
content: GLASGOW — The United Nations climate conference in Scotland has become a venue for world leaders and business executives to pretend they are taking action on climate change without following through, the climate activist Greta Thunberg said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How Californians Can Save More Water
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom has called for a 15 percent reduction in water usage, but we’re far from that target.
content: The results are in: Californians aren’t saving enough water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Damon Winter
title: 3,000 Miles From Glasgow, a Town and Its Polar Bears Face the Future
description: In Churchill, climate change is not a looming danger. It imbues daily life.
content: CHURCHILL, MANITOBA — This is not another story about saving Hudson Bay’s polar bears. It’s too late for that. This is a story about what comes next for a small town that bills itself as the Polar Bear Capital of the World.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Three Stars, Three Ways, Three Classic Plays
description: On British stages, Saoirse Ronan, Cush Jumbo and Ian McKellen present contrasting approaches to Shakespeare and Chekhov.
content: LONDON — Saoirse Ronan may be the main attraction of “The Tragedy of Macbeth,” as Shakespeare’s play is billed at the Almeida Theater, where it will run through Nov. 27. Yet, not for the first time in the director Yaël Farber’s career, Farber rules every minute of this attenuated account of the famously short work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: American Optimism, R.I.P.
description: Maybe it was always a myth. It’s at least a distant memory.
content: I thought that we were a sunny people. I thought that optimism was the fundamental nature of the United States of America, the whole point. We had an endless horizon that encouraged people to dream their biggest dreams. We were the hope when all other hope had run dry. We were, as Ronald Reagan loved to say, “a shining city upon a hill.” Look up — look skyward — to see us. Behold our glow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Back in Chicago, Woman Is Charged in Killing of Mother on Indonesian Vacation
description: Heather L. Mack, 26, had already served more than six years in prison in Indonesia for the 2014 killing of her mother, whose body was found in a suitcase at a Bali resort.
content: It was a homecoming of sorts when Heather L. Mack arrived at O’Hare International Airport in Chicago on Wednesday after having served more than six years in an Indonesian prison after the discovery of her mother’s body stuffed in a suitcase at a Bali resort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: Inspiration From The Times’s ‘It’s Never Too Late’ Series
description: In this lesson, students will read about people who pursued dreams later in life. Then, they will interview someone with a similar story, or make a plan to pursue a dream of their own.
content: Featured Series: “It’s Never Too Late”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Democrats, It’s Time to Get Moving
description: Pass something, and mandate vaccinations.
content: Democrats are engaging in a lot of soul-searching after Tuesday’s elections. Much of that soul-searching involves trying to find a better way to respond to the critical race theory attack; that attack was clearly effective even though it’s a dog whistle wrapped in a scam (public schools are not, in fact, teaching C.R.T.). However, I have nothing interesting to say about how to deal with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Is the Problem Facebook? Or the Internet?
description: Tech reporter Casey Newton takes us inside the Facebook Papers consortium, the company’s failure to be held to account and why the problem is bigger than any one company.
content: The Facebook Papers and whistle-blower testimony have given us yet more insight into the company’s impact on polarization and mental health, but if you could wave a magic wand and “pull the plug on Facebook,” would these problems go away? Casey Newton, the journalist behind the newsletter Platformer, says no. Imagining a universe where “Mark Zuckerberg is not the C.E.O., the company doesn’t exist — I actually don’t think you would improve the internet that much,” he says. He caveats that Facebook has never been held accountable “in any meaningful way,” but the problems are much bigger than any one platform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: The Platonic Ideal of Macaroni and Cheese
description: Inspired by Stouffer’s mac and cheese, in the red box from the freezer aisle, this homemade version delivers the same molten creaminess.
content: For those nostalgic enough to look into them, old restaurant menus, like telescopes, can reveal distant worlds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Nov. 10, 2021
description: Is the likelihood of solving a murder case less if the weapon is a gun?
content: This graph shows the relationship between the percentage of murders committed with guns for the 67 cities that had 30 or more murders in 2019 and the percentage of all murders solved. What is the association between the two variables shown in this graph, and why might they be associated in this way?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Hong Kong will offer extra shots to high-risk residents next week.
description: Hong Kong has said that it will offer free additional doses of Covid vaccines to residents with a higher risk of illness starting on Nov. 11.
content: Hong Kong has said that it will offer free additional doses of Covid vaccines to residents with a higher risk of illness starting on Nov. 11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karin Lipson
title: Manhattan Valley: A ‘More Affordable Pocket of the Upper West Side’
description: Residents treasure this attainable neighborhood near the top of Central Park, where ‘everyone has an interesting story to tell.’
content: After seeing 50 apartments in 2019, Keith Spencer knew he had found the place for him as soon as he entered the 51st: a fourth-floor co-op on West 105th Street, in the neighborhood known as Manhattan Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: After 14 Years, Robert Plant and Alison Krauss Finally Reunite
description: The duo worked with T Bone Burnett on the million-selling triumph “Raising Sand,” in 2007. Its sequel is once again an alternative to nearly all of its pop contemporaries.
content: “Raising Sand,” the 2007 duet album by Robert Plant and Alison Krauss, started as an experiment, a modest side project for two longtime bandleaders to revisit old and recent songs. It was a hushed, long-breathed album with a haunted twang, yet it turned into a blockbuster — selling more than a million copies and winning five Grammy Awards including album of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: Review: ‘This Is Not a War Story,’ Nor Does Coming Home Mean Peace
description: This poignant drama directed by and starring Talia Lugacy follows a traumatized Marine as she tries to connect with a group of fellow veterans at home.
content: “American Sniper,” “The Hurt Locker,” “Zero Dark Thirty,” “Saving Private Ryan” — “I hate those movies,” says Isabelle (Talia Lugacy), a U.S. Marine recently returned home from combat. Painfully inhibited, neglected by her family and racked with guilt over her meaninglessly violent actions overseas, Isabelle is not at ease in this world. She struggles to find reasons to go on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on the Uncapped Water Bottle
description: A “clumsy fellow” demands his partner be more conscientious with her hydration.
content: Sasha writes: My partner, Emily, has a tall, narrow water bottle that she insists on keeping uncapped. She also leaves it in random places around the kitchen. title: Should My Brother’s Bias Dictate Our Thanksgiving Plans?

content: For 10 years, I have hosted Thanksgiving for my extended family. My brother and his family always join us. This year, my wife and I were excited to welcome everyone to our new apartment in Manhattan. But my brother dismissed the idea: He said his family, including his wife and teenage daughters, are afraid to go to any city after the sweeping protests following the murder of George Floyd. I am annoyed that they’re placing more faith in their slanted newsfeeds, which amplified footage of disorderly demonstrators, than in our accounts of people marching passionately but peacefully in our neighborhood. We could always host at our small cottage in the country, but it would be cramped. Thoughts?

content: The New Museum’s fifth Triennial exhibition, titled “Soft Water Hard Stone,” is largely a product of lockdown. Much of the work by 40 international artists and collectives was made during the past two pandemic-strapped years. And it has, overall, a hoarded, shut-in feel. Colors are muted. Materials are scrappy, unpretty. (Concrete turns up a lot). Scale is generally small, and of the few monumental pieces, most are sculptures or installations in break-downable formats.

author: By David Graeber and David Wengrow
title: Ancient History Shows How We Can Create a More Equal World
description: New research on humanity's deep past holds lessons for the future.
content: Most of human history is irreparably lost to us. Our species, Homo sapiens, has existed for at least 200,000 years, but we have next to no idea what was happening for the majority of that time. In northern Spain, for instance, at the cave of Altamira, paintings and engravings were created over a period of at least 10,000 years, between around 25,000 and 15,000 B.C. Presumably, a lot of dramatic events occurred during that period. We have no way of knowing what most of them were. This is of little consequence to most people, since most people rarely think about the broad sweep of human history anyway. They don’t have much reason to. Insofar as the question comes up at all, it’s usually when reflecting on why the world seems to be in such a mess and why human beings so often treat each other badly — the reasons for war, greed, exploitation and indifference to others’ suffering. Were we always like that, or did something, at some point, go terribly wrong?
